content:
Diagnosis:	Poorly differentiated thyroid carcinoma, T4N1M1 with lung and bone metastases
	Diagnosed March 2024 following FNA of 6.8cm right thyroid mass
	Molecular profile: TP53 and TERT mutations identified
?
[redacted name] is a 62-year-old gentleman who has unfortunately been diagnosed with an aggressive poorly differentiated thyroid carcinoma. He initially presented to his GP in January 2024 with a rapidly enlarging right-sided neck mass and progressive dysphagia to solids. A subsequent ultrasound revealed a 6.8cm highly suspicious right thyroid mass with multiple pathological appearing cervical lymph nodes. FNA biopsy confirmed poorly differentiated thyroid carcinoma.
?
Staging investigations including CT neck/chest/abdomen/pelvis on 15/03/24 demonstrated the primary thyroid mass extending into the tracheal wall with multiple bilateral cervical lymph nodes. There were also multiple bilateral pulmonary metastases, the largest measuring 2.2cm, and lytic bone metastases affecting T4, T8 vertebrae and the left acetabulum. MRI spine on 20/03/24 confirmed the vertebral metastases with no evidence of cord compression. Molecular testing has identified both TP53 and TERT mutations, which are associated with more aggressive disease behavior.
?
He reports worsening dysphagia requiring modification of diet to soft foods, and has lost 7kg in weight over 2 months. He describes new onset bone pain affecting his mid-back and left hip, currently requiring regular co-codamol. His performance status has declined from fully independent to ECOG PS 2 due to pain and fatigue.
?
In his past medical history, he has well-controlled type 2 diabetes on metformin, and hypertension managed with amlodipine. He lives with his wife who provides good support, and has two adult children living nearby. He is an ex-smoker having quit 10 years ago with a 30 pack-year history.
?
On examination today, there is a hard, fixed 7cm right thyroid mass with associated right cervical lymphadenopathy. There is mild stridor at rest. Chest examination reveals reduced breath sounds at both bases. There is tenderness over the thoracic spine and left hip.
?
I have discussed his case in detail with our thyroid MDT. Given the aggressive nature of his disease and presence of distant metastases, we recommend systemic therapy with the multikinase inhibitor lenvatinib. I have explained the aims of treatment, focusing on disease control and symptom improvement, as well as potential side effects including hypertension, fatigue, and diarrhea. We will also refer urgently for palliative radiotherapy to the symptomatic bone metastases.
?
The plan is to admit him next week for initiation of lenvatinib under close monitoring given his stridor. I have arranged urgent referral to palliative care for optimization of pain control, and he will have a DEXA scan and dental review prior to consideration of bone-targeted therapy. We will see him again in clinic in 2 weeks with repeat thyroid function tests and biochemistry.
